title-group.article-title: Spark ignition to homogeneous charge compression ignition mode transition study: a new modelling approach

abstract.p: A hybrid spark ignition/homogeneous charge compression ignition engine model for simulating the spark ignition to homogeneous charge compression ignition transition in a four-cylinder gasoline engine is presented. This hybrid spark ignition/homogeneous charge compression ignition model has been developed to provide help in understanding the complicated spark ignition to homogeneous charge compression ignition transition process and in tackling the control problems associated with it. The model was built in Matlab/Simulink, coupled with a tabulated stochastic reactor model and a detailed chemical kinetics mechanism. Typical computational times encountered in the simulation using this model were of the order of seconds for one engine cycle. The model was validated in steady-state spark ignition and homogeneous charge compression ignition operation by experimental data, followed by model-based parametric studies in homogeneous charge compression ignition operation. Then, a spark ignition to homogeneous charge compression ignition mode transition was simulated using the model. The results showed good agreement with experimental data, in terms of cylinder pressure, combustion phasing, air/fuel ratio, residual gas fraction and nitrogen oxides. The high computational efficiency and relatively high accuracy of this model enable its good applicability in experimental design and controller development, and potential use in hardware-in-loop applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) combustion is a combustion mode in which a more or less homogeneous mixture of air, fuel and trapped exhaust gas is auto-ignited through compression. It has the potential to significantly reduce nitrogen oxide (NOx) and particulate matter (PM) emissions and improve fuel economy by 15–20%, while potentially having the capability of operating with a variety of fuels.1 Thus, it is widely considered to be one possible technology for future internal combustion engines to meet the strict requirements in engine emissions and fuel consumption.

However, the operation range of a gasoline HCCI engine is limited by knocking at high load and misfiring at low load. Although some progress has been made to enlarge the HCCI operating window in recent research,2–6 it is still far from covering the entire engine operating map. Furthermore, for HCCI engines that use trapped residual gas at high temperatures as means of initiating combustion, it is necessary for the engine to start in spark ignition (SI) mode. As a result, an SI–HCCI–SI mode switch is needed to implement HCCI combustion in real applications, such that HCCI combustion could be used for medium and low loads, while SI combustion can be employed for very low load and high load operations and cold start.

The switches between the two combustion modes should be seamless in terms of engine torque and noise to the driver, certainly without misfiring or knocking, and fast enough to satisfy the driver’s demand for rapid changes in engine power. Fuel consumption penalties and emission penalties, which could possibly occur during the transition, also need to be seriously considered.

In the last few years, the SI–HCCI–SI mode switch has been widely studied,7–15 mainly by experiments. With the aid of fully variable valve actuation systems, the mode switches can be achieved without great difficulties, but load fluctuations, misfiring and knocking were observed during the transitions. Therefore, a further understanding of the complex process and tackling the control problems associated with it are required. Solely experimental exploration would be ineffective, expensive and impractical, as there are many variables that exhibit complex interactions during the mode transitions. Although significant research efforts have been led to develop HCCI engine models,16–32 only a few modelling approaches for SI–HCCI–SI transition14,33–36 can be found in the literature, and detailed chemical kinetic modelling of SI–HCCI–SI transition36 has not been available until very recently. However, the previously developed SI–HCCI–SI models, which either adopted one-step single chemical reaction mechanisms or failed to capture much of the transient dynamics during the mode transitions, resulting in poor accuracy in combustion phase and emission predictions, suggest a more comprehensive SI–HCCI–SI modelling approach with detailed chemical reaction mechanisms is needed.

In this paper, a new hybrid SI/HCCI model is presented. It has been developed in Matlab/Simulink and Fortran, coupled with a tabulated stochastic reactor model (SRM) with detailed chemical kinetic mechanisms, enabling fast evaluation in transient multi-cycle simulations. An experimental investigation in SI–HCCI–SI transitions is also described, in which cyclic air/fuel ratio (AFR) and residual gas fraction (RGF) measurements were taken using novel experimental techniques. The model was then validated by the experimental data both in steady-state SI and HCCI operations, and parametric studies in HCCI operation were conducted using this validated model. Finally, an SI to HCCI mode transition was simulated using this model and the results provided an insight into the complicated transition process.

sec.title: Construction of a hybrid SI/HCCI engine model
sec.p: The hybrid SI/HCCI engine model is a simulation of a four-cylinder hybrid SI/HCCI gasoline engine. An established SRM37–39 is used to simulate combustion, turbulent mixing, convective heat transfer and direct injections during the closed valve portion of the engine cycle and employs detailed chemical kinetics. A previously developed tabulation technique40 has been implemented for the SRM model, which stores, retrieves and interpolates output quantities of the entire SRM engine model. These quantities include in-cylinder pressure and temperature, cumulative heat release and emissions of CO, CO2, unburnt hydrocarbons (uHCs) and NOx, as functions of fuel mass, exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) ratio and in-cylinder temperature at inlet valve closing (IVC), for example. The tables generated by the SRM are coupled with a one-dimensional Matlab/Simulink engine model for computing the gas exchange process during the open valve portion of the engine cycle. The SI to HCCI mode change is achieved by several changes in actuation, mainly by shifting the intake and exhaust valve timings.

The gas exchange and overall engine model has been built in Matlab/Simulink.41 The tabulated SRM model, which is called the combustion core in this paper, has been developed in Fortran42 to achieve a high computing efficiency. Level-2 M-File S-Functions in Matlab are used as the interface between Fortran and Matlab/Simulink. The model structure is shown in Figure 1. The gas exchange, the combustion core and the SI to HCCI mode switch are introduced in the following three subsections.

sec.title: Gas exchange
sec.p: During the gas exchange process, the engine is modelled as an open thermodynamic system. The gas flow is assumed to be quasi steady and is computed by using steady one-dimensional flow equations. The cylinders and the intake and exhaust manifolds are considered as a series of interconnected components with significant flow restrictions. These components are connected by the gas flow passing through them, the pressures across them and the mass accumulation between them. The mass and energy conservation equations coupled with mass flow rates are used to define the gas state in each control volume.

The governing equations for the model during the gas exchange process are mass and energy conservations for a control volume, the ideal gas law and the flow rate equations. Here, kinetic and potential energies were ignored as the change rate of potential energy is negligible and the kinetic energy change rate is relatively small.43

In internal combustion (IC) engines, the working fluids can usually be treated as ideal gases. Therefore, the thermodynamic properties of the mixture gases obey the ideal gas law. During the gas exchange process, the mixture gases are assumed to be made up of the following species: N2, O2, H2O vapour, CO2, CO, NO, NO2 and fuel vapour, and the gas composition in the cylinder is assumed to be spatially homogeneous. For each individual species, the specific heat at constant volume cv and the specific heat at constant pressure cp are functions of temperature only. In this model, look-up tables of cv and cp for each species have been built from JANAF data,44 with the temperature as the input. For the gas mixture, once the composition is known, mixture properties are determined by the mass fraction of each species and its properties.

The intake manifold was simulated in a similar way, as the cylinders and the exhaust manifold model used a plenum method, assuming the pressure in the exhaust manifold is constant. A time splitting algorithm was then used to solve the above models, as depicted in Figure 2. Variable t0 corresponds to time at intake or exhaust valve opening (EVO). The in-cylinder pressure pc, temperature Tc, mass mc and species concentrations xj at t0 are specified by the combustion core, denoted by pc0, Tc0, mc0 and xj0. The intake manifold air pressure (MAP) and mass are set to an initial value pi0 and mi0, respectively. Δt is the deterministic global time step that is used for operator splitting. It is 0.2 crank angle degrees (CAD) in this model. With time marching, the gas states in the cylinders, the intake manifold and the exhaust manifold are calculated.

It is worth noting that in reality, the intake and exhaust flows are pulsating and the instantaneous pressures always fluctuate. The prediction of them is much more complicated. However, since the goal is to provide the input conditions to a detailed model of in-cylinder processes, sophisticated intake and exhaust system models are not necessary for this work. A further discussion on the air pressure fluctuation caused by wave action is given in the subsection on variable valve timing (VVT) and MAP.

sec.title: Combustion core
sec.p: As already mentioned in this paper, the tables that store, retrieve and interpolate output quantities of the entire SRM model using the tabulation technique, are called the combustion core. The SRM model is a spatially zero-dimensional model based on probability density function (PDF) transport methods.53 It considers scalars, such as temperature, mass fraction, etc., as random variables with a certain probability distribution. The cylinder charge is split into an ensemble of particles that make up the PDF of temperature and composition. In-cylinder turbulence is accounted for using the Euclidean minimum spanning tree (EMST) mixing model,54 which takes into account localness in composition space. Stochastic heat transfer and direct injection sub-models are also included.

For SI simulation, the particle ensemble is divided into three zones: unburned, entrained and burned. Mixing occurs within each zone, but not between zones, and all particles are initially in the unburned zone. The diameter of the entrained zone at the time of spark was set to 1.0 mm, the rough size of the spark gap. The first particle randomly chosen to enter the entrained zone is not added all at once, but the actual entrained volume is removed from it and added to a new particle in the entrained zone. Once the entrained volume has increased above the particle’s volume, it is reunited into a single particle. The spark is simulated by setting the temperature of the mass added to the entrained zone at each step to 2000 K, until all of the spark energy has been added. A particle is moved from the unburned zone to the entrained zone when the calculated flame volume exceeds the burned and entrained zone volumes by more than half the volume of the next particle to be entrained. The volume of the flame is calculated from the geometry of the piston and cylinder, and the flame radius assuming it is spherical and centred at the spark location. More details about the SI model can be found in Etheridge et al.55,56

The SRM model uses a detailed primary reference fuel (PRF) chemical kinetic mechanism, which was developed by combining the iso-octane and n-heptane mechanisms,21,22 containing 157 species and 1552 reactions. These mechanisms included a high-temperature sub-mechanism for temperatures above 900 K, which is dominated by H atom abstraction from the fuel, followed by radical thermal decomposition to smaller species. The dominant chain-branching mechanisms in this temperature range include the reaction H + O2 = O + OH. These detailed kinetic mechanisms also included reaction pathways important at lower temperatures, roughly between 600 K and 850 K, which are initiated by addition of molecular oxygen to alkyl and other radical species to produce alkylperoxy radicals. These alkylperoxy species then isomerise, then decompose or add further O2, leading to chain-branching sequences that are unique to these lower temperatures. The H2–O2–CO–CO2 chemistry was taken from Yetter et al.57 The SRM model was previously developed by Kraft et al.37 with a detailed natural gas chemical kinetic mechanism, and was incorporated to the PRF chemical kinetic mechanism in Bhave et al.58 It has been validated in previous studies.59,60

In order to achieve a high computational efficiency, a previously developed tabulation technique by Mosbach et al.40 was adopted and implemented for this SRM engine model. The technique uses the full SRM to pre-tabulate important outputs from the model, such as cumulative heat release, in-cylinder pressure and temperature and emissions, as functions of operating variables, such as fuel mass and EGR ratio. A fast scheme is then used to retrieve and interpolate the pre-tabulated data, replacing the much more computationally expensive SRM calculations.

The model was designed to simulate a hybrid SI/HCCI engine, which operates in SI mode with normal valve overlap and HCCI mode with a large negative valve overlap (NVO). In HCCI mode, fuel is injected into the cylinder early in the NVO period, and significant fuel reforming and heat release takes place. The SI to HCCI mode transition is complicated to simulate, as two modes of combustion are present, along with the heat release during the NVO period. This means that different tables are required at different points in the transition so that suitable input parameters can be chosen at each stage of the mode switch.

Six tables were generated for the SI to HCCI transition: an SI table, a first NVO table, a transition NVO table, a steady NVO table, a transition HCCI table and a steady HCCI table. The SI table simulates the normal SI combustion. In HCCI mode, the NVO and HCCI tables simulate the heat release during NVO (also called NVO combustion) and the main combustion, respectively.

The first table required in the transition is the SI table. The input parameters to the table were required to cope with changes in fuel mass and spark timing, as these parameters can be used to control the transition. As the opening of the throttle can affect the final SI cycle, it was necessary to include the temperature and pressure at IVC as well. The EGR mass was assumed to remain constant in SI combustion.

Separate tables for transient NVO and the first NVO were produced due to the difference in exhaust gas composition from SI and HCCI combustion. Although named the first NVO table, it was also used in some cylinders for the second NVO due to large amounts of ‘SI’ flame propagation in the first HCCI cycle. The fuel injection timing and amount were taken as control inputs that could be optimised. The temperature and pressure at exhaust valve closing (EVC) were required to cope with fluctuations due to the previous combustions and the VVT phasing. The fuel/air equivalence ratio ϕ was used as a fifth input to provide the O2 mass fraction at EVC, which has an important effect on the NVO heat release. The transition NVO table was similar to the first NVO table, apart from the O2 mass fraction being used as an input instead of the fuel/air equivalence ratio ϕ.

The steady NVO table did not require the EVC pressure as its input, since it was used for NVOs after the VVT phasing has finished. The four parameters chosen for this table were the same as the transition NVO table input parameters, except the EVC pressure.

The transition HCCI table needs to include fuel mass and spark timing for the same reasons as the SI table, and also the temperature and pressure at IVC. As the EVC phase is advanced and the intake MAP is increased during the transition, the EGR mass was changed cycle-by-cycle. Therefore, it was also chosen as an input.

For the steady HCCI table, it was possible to remove the IVC pressure because the table was used after the intake MAP had stabilised and the VVT phasing had finished. EGR mass was assumed to remain constant. The spark timing was also no longer required due to it having little to no effect on HCCI combustion in steady state. The IVC temperature and fuel mass were then chosen as inputs along with the NVO heat release and NVO fuel mass. The NVO parameters were used to obtain an EGR composition. This was done by using the output compositions from the NVO table simulations. At each NVO fuel mass, each component mass fraction was fitted to a cubic function of the NVO heat release. The fit was then saved in the steady-state HCCI, which was remarkably good and allowed the HCCI table to take into account how reacted the fuel injected was during NVO.

A summary of the inputs for the six tables are shown in Table 1. The outputs of all the tables are the in-cylinder temperature, pressure and mass, the cumulative heat release, the fuel/air equivalence ratio and mole fractions of O2, CO, CO2, NO, NO2 and uHCs in terms of C1–C8.

sec.title: SI to HCCI mode switch
sec.p: The model initially runs in SI mode with a high-lift cam profile and then switches into HCCI mode by a set of changes in actuation. A mode switch signal has been defined by a specified crank angle, which provided a crank-angle-based reference. All the actuation changes, including cam profile shifting, VVT phasing and throttle opening, are implemented on a crank-angle basis relative to the mode switch signal. The closed loop hydraulic operation of the VVT phasing is modelled as a second-order transfer function augmented by a delay given by
In a similar fashion, the transfer function from throttle command to throttle opening is

The factors in the transfer functions were calibrated by the experimental measurements, and more details will be given in the subsection on VVT and MAP. Fuel injection timing and amount, and spark timing are changed on a cyclic basis. The counting starts from the mode switch signal as well.

As mentioned in the previous subsections, six different pre-calculated tables were used in the SI to HCCI transition process. The first table required is the SI table, which simulates the normal SI combustion. When the SI to HCCI transition was triggered, the cam profile switched from high lift to low lift immediately, enabling NVO to trap exhaust gas. Because the trapped exhaust gas from SI combustion had different composition from HCCI combustion, the special generated first NVO table was called by the combustion core to simulate the fuel reforming in the absence of oxygen, during the NVO period in the first HCCI cycle. The throttle opening and the VVT timing also started changing in the first HCCI cycle and took a few cycles to reach the steady status, resulting in a few transient HCCI cycles. For the rest of the transient cycles after the first HCCI cycle, the transition NVO table was used to simulate the NVO combustion, where oxygen was presented. For all the transit cycles (including the first HCCI cycle), the transition HCCI table was adopted for simulating the main combustion in HCCI mode. Finally, after the VVT timing and the throttle opening reached the steady status, the steady NVO table and the steady HCCI table were adopted to simulate steady-state NVO combustion and main combustion in the HCCI mode separately. The switch of the tables in the engine model was also triggered on a cyclic basis relative to the mode switch signal. This mode switch strategy is illustrated in Figure 3.

caption.p: Illustration of SI to HCCI mode switch in the engine model (Trans.: transition).

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p: The engine used for this study was a Ford 2.0 l four-cylinder gasoline diesel engine (GDI) engine, which is equipped with hydraulic two-stage profile camshafts. There was no external EGR loop. The configuration of the engine and facility is almost the same as reported in a previous study.61 The engine speed is controlled by a dynamometer and a torque output reading is given by a dynamometer load cell. Each cylinder is fitted with a Kistler 6123 piezoelectric pressure transducer coupled to charge amplifiers. An optical encoder provides engine rotational position information, triggering ADC (analog-to-digital converter) cards for high-frequency data recording. Thermocouples attached to the intake and exhaust manifolds provide temperature readings. The fuel flow rate was obtained from a Coriolis-type flow meter. Engine specifications are listed in Table 2 and the valve timing is illustrated in Figure 4.

sec.p: To be able to determine the cyclic AFR of each cylinder, previously developed fast universal exhaust gas oxygen (UEGO) sensors62–64 were connected to the exhaust manifold via sample capillaries located close to the exhaust ports. The fast UEGO sensors are based on the standard UEGO sensor, but have a time constant in the range 8–12 ms. To measure instantaneous RGF, two Cambustion NDIR500 fast response non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) analysers were used to measure the cyclic concentration of CO2 in the compression stroke and in the exhaust. The NDIR unit sampling in-cylinder gas is connected to a Cambustion compact sampling valve (CSV) high-speed sampling valve, which itself is connected directly to the combustion chamber of Cylinder 4, via a small hole drilled in the cylinder head, just above the head face. The CSV enables a timed gas sample to be extracted during the main compression stroke. The second NDIR analyser is connected to the exhaust manifold of Cylinder 4 by sharing the same sample capillary as fast UEGO 4. The entire sampling system is shown in Figure 5.

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: The model validation was conducted by comparing cylinder pressure, combustion characteristics, AFR, RGF and emissions of experimental data to the corresponding outputs of the model. The experiment and simulation was run at a nominal operating point of 2.2 bar brake mean effective pressure (BMEP) and 1500 r/min engine speed with other operating parameters listed in Table 3. The SI–HCCI mode transition in this paper was conducted between these two conditions as well.

sec.title: Model validation in steady HCCI operation
sec.p: For the HCCI operating point listed in Table 3, the average pressure profiles of 20 simulated and 100 experimental engine cycles are shown in Figure 6. The simulation results match experimental data reasonably well.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles of 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles in HCCI operation.

sec.p: The NVO combustion phases are compared in Figure 7 and suggest the modelled NVO combustion occurs slightly later and has shorter combustion duration. The average heat release of NVO combustion in the simulation is 43 J, which is higher than that in the experiment of 33 J. The likely reason is that the actual ratio of pilot fuel to total fuel in the experiment is lower than the nominal split factor, which was used in the simulation. This is because the split factor comes from the ratio of injector voltage pulse widths during each injection in the experiment and the delay before the fuel flow rate through the injector reaches its maximum taking up a higher percentage of injection time for a shorter injection period, which is usually the pilot injection. So a higher amount of fuel was injected during the NVO period in the simulation, which caused a lower temperature and then a later auto-ignition due to the fuel evaporation. Therefore, before the NVO combustion, a lower pressure occurred in the simulation, as shown in Figure 8. More pilot fuel in the simulation also caused higher NVO heat release and resulted in a higher temperature and pressure after the NVO combustion, which is also shown in Figure 8. This possible reason was further echoed by comparing this modelled pressure profile to the experimental data with a split factor of 0.76. The modelled pressure profile shows a better agreement with the lower split factor experimental data, as shown in Figure 9.

caption.p: 5%, 50% and 90% MFB points during NVO combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles.
Average pressure profiles during NVO period of 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles.

sec.p: The average pressure profiles during the main combustion are shown in Figure 10. The modelled cylinder pressure matches the experimental data well, although the after-peak pressure was slightly lower than in the experiment. Figure 11 shows the heat release analysis, which suggests the simulation has a good agreement with the experiment on the combustion phase, in terms of the 5% and 50% mass fraction burned (MFB) points. It also suggests the simulation has a slightly earlier 90% MFB point, indicating shorter combustion duration. The average heat release of main combustion in the simulation was 200 J, which was lower than that in the experiment of 242 J. The main reason for this difference is likely to be due to the extra fuel injected for the main combustion due to a lower ratio of pilot fuel to total fuel in the experiment, as mentioned above. The lower heat release, combined with the shorter combustion duration, mainly caused the lower after-peak pressure in the simulation.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles during main combustion of 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles.
5%, 50% and 90% MFB points during main combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles.

sec.p: Modelled peak pressures against the crank angle at which they occurred for 20 consecutive cycles are compared with 100 consecutive experimental cycles in Figure 12. The simulation shows slightly earlier peak pressures. It is possibly caused by the shorter combustion duration, indicated by the earlier 90% MFB point in Figure 11.

caption.p: Peak pressures against the crank angles at which they occurred for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles.

sec.p: In Figures 7 and 11, the experimental data shows strong cycle-to-cycle fluctuations in combustion phases. This is possibly because an early main combustion caused less O2 trapped in the next NVO, which decreased NVO heat release and fuel reforming effects. Therefore, the main combustion in the next cycle was delayed. Alternatively, a larger amount of O2 was trapped in the NVO after a late main combustion, which increased the NVO heat release and fuel reforming effects, resulting in an earlier main combustion in the next cycle. The model captured this trend, but shows smaller cycle-to-cycle variations. A possible reason is that the simulated NVO heat release and fuel reforming effects have smaller variations due to less mass fluctuation of trapped O2 in the NVO.

The average relative AFR obtained in the simulation is 1.41, which has a good agreement with the measured value of 1.38. The modelled average RGF is 48%, compared with a measured value of 52%. These values are important, as poor matches would suggest incorrect in-cylinder mass and temperatures at IVC and EVC.

The average CO2 emission (mole fraction) obtained in the simulation is 9.00%, which is about 10% lower than the measured value of 9.95%. The main reason is the fuels used in the simulation and experiment have different C : H ratios. The fuel used in the experiment was 95 research octane number (RON) gasoline with C : H = 6.33 : 11.46, and the fuel used in the simulation was PRF 80 fuel with C : H = 8 : 17.6. The reason for using PRF 80 fuel in the HCCI simulation is because the actual RON of the fuel is higher than the octane index (OI) due to the higher IVC temperature in HCCI operation.

The average NOx emissions in the simulation were 1 ppm, which in the order of magnitude is comparable to the measured value, 15.2 ppm. Since NOx emissions are mainly determined by temperature in a lean combustion, this suggests temperature in the simulation was a good match to the experiment. However, because the original SRM model, which was used to generate the combustion cores, contained a crevice, but no wall impingement sub-model, the uHC and CO emissions obtained in the simulation were about one third of the measured values. The low values could also be due to the assumption of a homogeneous charge at IVC.

sec.title: Model validation in steady SI operation
sec.p: The model validation in steady-state SI operation was conducted in a similar way to the steady-state HCCI operation. The experiment and simulation were run at the same nominal operating point of 2.2 bar BMEP and 1500 r/min engine speed, with the settings shown in Table 3.

The average pressure profiles of 20 simulated and 100 experimental steady-state SI cycles are shown in Figure 13, and the average pressures during combustion are compared in Figure 14. The simulation matches the experiment reasonably well, with a slightly higher peak pressure and a slightly lower after-peak pressure, which are possibly caused by an earlier and shorter combustion in the simulation and the effect of averaging the pressure profiles of experimental data.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles in SI operation.
Average pressure profiles during combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles in SI operation.

sec.p: Heat release analysis in Figure 15 suggests the start of combustion was 2 CAD earlier and the combustion duration was 4 CAD shorter in the simulation compared with the experiment. Figure 15 shows large cycle-to-cycle variations in the experiment, which could not be predicted by the engine model. This is because throttle opening, injected fuel mass and spark timing were kept constant, which resulted in a stable IVC pressure and IVC temperature in the simulation. Therefore, the outputs of the model were fixed, as all the inputs of the SI combustion table were kept constant in the steady-state SI operation. The prediction of cycle-to-cycle variations in SI operation is also out of the scope of this model.

caption.p: 5%, 50% and 90% MFB points for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles in SI operation.

sec.p: The average relative AFR obtained in the simulation is 1.02, which has a good agreement with the measured value of 1.01. The modelled average RGF is 33.3%, very close to a measured value of 32%. The CO2 emission (mole fraction) obtained in the simulation was 12.22%, lower than the measured value, which was 14.46%. The main reason is likely that PRF 95 fuel (C : H = 8 : 17.9), which was used in the simulation, has a different C : H ratio from 95 RON gasoline (C : H = 6.33 : 11.46), which was used in the experiment. The NOx mole fraction obtained in the simulation was 336 ppm, close to the measured value of 321 ppm. However, similar to the HCCI operation, the uHC and CO emissions obtained in the simulation were much less than the measured values.

sec.title: Parametric studies in HCCI operation
sec.p: The validated model was then used to conduct parametric studies in HCCI operation. Different fuel split factors and pilot injection timings were used as shown in Table 4. Here, Case 3 is the base case, which was used for the model validation in the previous section.

caption.p: Fuel split factors and pilot injection timings of Cases 1–5.

sec.title: Fuel split factor
sec.p: Fuel split factors were varied in Cases 1–3 as shown in Table 4. The average NVO pressure profiles are compared in Figure 16 and main combustion in Figure 17. The simulation results show a good match, in all three cases, with the experimental data and followed the trend of combustion phase advancing.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles during NVO for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different fuel split factors.
Average pressure profiles during main combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different fuel split factors.

sec.p: The pressure before NVO combustion was lower when the fuel mass injected during NVO was increased. This was due to the evaporation of the fuel cooling the charge. In the experiment, after the NVO combustion, the pressure with more fuel injected is higher due to a higher NVO heat release. However, the same trend was not observed in the simulation, as shown in Figure 18. A possible reason is less fuel was injected during NVO in the experiment than the nominal value, as mentioned in the section on model validation, which caused a relatively leaner condition. Therefore, more fuel could be burned in the experiment than in the simulation when the fuel amount was increased.

caption.p: Average heat release during NVO for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles and modelled EVC and IVC temperatures with different fuel split factors.

sec.p: Combustion phases during main combustion are compared in Figure 19, which clearly shows a decrease in the fuel split factor causes an advanced main combustion in the experiment. The same trend was observed in the simulation. The advance in combustion phase was due to increased NVO heat release and due to the fuel becoming more reactive from reactions during the NVO period. The average modelled IVC temperatures in Cases 1–3 are shown in Figure 18 and only show a slight variation, as does the NVO heat release. This suggests the fuel reforming effect is the main reason for advanced combustion phase in the simulation when more fuel was injected in NVO. Higher increase of NVO heat release was observed in the experiment, which was the reason for further combustion phase advancing in the experiment compared with the simulation, as shown in Figure 19.

caption.p: Average combustion phases during main combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different fuel split factors.

sec.p: The NOx emissions increased, as shown in Figure 20, when more fuel was injected during the NVO period in the simulation, which matches the experimental trend very well, although the values are different. This is probably because the advanced combustion is closer to top dead centre (TDC), resulting in higher peak pressures and temperatures.

caption.p: NOx emissions for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different split factors.

sec.title: Pilot fuel injection timing
sec.p: Pilot fuel injection timings were varied in the simulation and experiment, which are shown in Table 4 and referred to as Cases 3–5. The average NVO pressure profiles in the simulation and experiment are compared in Figure 21 for the three cases. The peak pressure was increased when the pilot fuel injection timing was advanced in the experiment. The same trend was seen in the simulation. This was caused by increased NVO heat release, as shown in Figure 22, which also resulted in a higher IVC temperature. It is because the fuel residence time in the cylinder was increased when an earlier injection occurred, which allowed more time for chemical reactions.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles during NVO for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different pilot fuel injection timings (SOI: start of injection).
Average heat release during NVO for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles and modelled EVC and IVC temperatures with different pilot fuel injection timings.

sec.p: The average main combustion pressure profiles are compared in Figure 23, which shows an advance in pilot fuel injection timing, resulting in an advanced main combustion. Heat release analysis in Figure 24 clearly shows this trend in the simulation and experiment. The trend between Cases 3 and 4 in the simulation has a better match with the experiment than between Cases 3 and 5. The main reason is the heat release in the simulation and experiment had a similar increase between Cases 3 and 4, and so did the IVC temperatures, which is the primary reason for combustion phase advancing in the main combustion.

caption.p: Average pressure profiles during main combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different pilot fuel injection timings.
Average combustion phases during main combustion for 20 simulated and 100 experimental cycles with different pilot fuel injection timings.

sec.title: Model prediction and discussion for SI to HCCI mode transition
sec.p: An SI to HCCI mode transition of a four-cylinder engine was simulated using this hybrid SI/HCCI engine model. The engine operating points, where the SI to HCCI mode transition was taken, were listed in Table 3. The simulation results and discussion are presented in this section.

sec.title: VVT and MAP
sec.p: The VVT phasing was modelled as a second-order transfer function augmented by a delay as described in equation (12). The start of the VVT phasing is adjustable in the model and was manually set to match the start of the transition in the experiment. The other parameters in the transfer function were calibrated to match the modelled VVT outputs to the measured values, in terms of EVC and inlet valve opening (IVO) timing, as shown in Figure 25.

caption.p: Changes in VVT and MAP during SI to HCCI mode transition.

sec.p: The change of the throttle opening was modelled in a similar method as the VVT phasing as described in equation (13). The start of the change in throttle opening is also adjustable in the model and was manually set to match experimental throttle opening time. Coupled with the intake manifold sub-model, the intake MAP was modelled. Other parameters in the throttle opening transfer function were calibrated to match the modelled MAP increase to the measured value during the transition, as shown in Figure 25.

The model also provided an accurate prediction of the cycle-to-cycle MAP oscillation caused by the gas induction process, as shown in Figure 25. However, as mentioned in the subsection on gas exchange, the model is unable to capture the air pressure fluctuation caused by wave action. However, because the fluctuation occurs at the speed of sound, the wave can travel up and down in the manifold in about 2.9 ms (the length of the intake manifold is about 0.5 m). For the engine used in this research, the intake event takes 14.2 and 25.3 ms for the HCCI and the SI mode respectively, at an engine speed of 1500 r/min. This means the fluctuation wave could travel up and down the intake manifold several times during the induction process. Therefore, though wave action is potentially of relevance, it has not been investigated in this study.

sec.title: SI to HCCI transition in Cylinder 4
sec.p: In this subsection, the experimental and modelled results from Cylinder 4 are compared, since AFR, RGF and emissions were cyclically measured in this cylinder. The mode transitions of the other cylinders will be discussed in the next subsection.

The modelled and experimental pressure profiles during NVO and main combustion are compared in Figures 26 and 27, respectively. The relative AFR and RGF are compared in Figure 28. Net indicated mean effective pressure (NIMEP) and associated fuel injection amount are plotted in Figure 29. The CO2 and NOx emissions are shown in Figure 30. The modelled results match the experimental data extremely well.

caption.p: Pressure profiles during NVO period of Cylinder 4 in SI to HCCI mode transition.
Pressure profiles during main combustion of Cylinder 4 in SI to HCCI mode transition.
Relative AFR and RGF of Cylinder 4 during SI to HCCI mode transition.
NIMEP and fuel injection amount of Cylinder 4 during SI to HCCI mode transition.
CO2 and NOx emissions of Cylinder 4 during SI to HCCI mode transition.

sec.p: Figures 26(a) and (b) show cylinder pressure during NVO, obtained from the model and experimental data, respectively. The NVO peak pressure increased in the consecutive cycles from the first to the fourth HCCI cycle because of the EVC timing advancing. Little NVO heat release was observed in the first two HCCI cycles, both in the simulation and experiment, which was due to a low amount of O2 present and a late pilot fuel injection. The simulation shows longer NVO durations in the first and second HCCI cycles, which is possibly because the effective flow area in the simulation was smaller than in the experiment when the intake and exhaust valves were near closed. The measured value of EVC timing was slightly less than the modelled results in the fourth HCCI cycle, which is possibly the reason for a higher NVO peak pressure in the experiment.
Cylinder pressures during main combustion obtained from the model and experimental data are shown in Figures 27(a) and (b), respectively. A cycle-by-cycle discussion is given in the following.

list-item.p: The last SI cycle (−1 SI, the SI table called) shows an earlier ignition, a faster pressure rise ratio and a higher peak pressure than the previous cycle due to extra fuel injected and an earlier ignition timing. The relative AFR dropped and RGF was kept almost the same because extra fuel was injected and the MAP had not yet increased. The CO2 and NOx emissions decreased as the cylinder charge became richer.

The first HCCI cycle (1 HCCI, the first NVO table and the transition HCCI table called) exhibits a mixing of flame propagation and auto-ignition. SI combustion occurred after the spark event and HCCI was triggered later in the compression stroke. Without the spark, misfire was observed in both the simulation and experiment. The modelled result shows a more HCCI-like combustion, possibly because the simulation has a leaner mixture, so the flame propagation was compromised. The leaner mixture also caused a larger drop of CO2 emission in the simulation. The RGF slightly increased due to the valve lift switches. The SI and HCCI combined combustion caused a high peak temperature, which, coupled with a leaner mixture, resulted in high NOx emissions.

The second HCCI cycle (2 HCCI, the transition NVO table and the transition HCCI table called) had a lower RGF and a higher relative AFR. This is due to an increased MAP and a slow response of VVT shifting, as shown in Figure 25. As a result, the IVC temperature was low and the density of the in-cylinder mixture was elevated. Simulation results have shown the IVC temperature in this cycle was 485°C, about 40°C lower than the steady-state value of 524°C. The modelled in-cylinder mass in this cycle was about 5% more than in the steady-state cycles. The auto-ignition was triggered at the end of the compression stroke. The combustion duration was very short and the pressure rise rate was extremely high, possibly due to the highly homogeneous mixture. The NOx emissions dropped as the peak temperature was lower than the previous cycle.

In the third HCCI cycle (3 HCCI, the transition NVO table and the transition HCCI table called), a high RGF value was achieved as the VVT timing was close to the steady-state value. As a result, the modelled IVC temperature increased to 515°C, close to the steady-state value of 524°C. The simulation has shown a later auto-ignition in this cycle, but a reversed trend was observed in the experiment. This is because of the higher RGF in the experiment, which possibly caused a higher IVC temperature, resulting in an earlier auto-ignition. The NOx emissions in the simulation were close to zero as the peak temperature was further decreased.

The fourth HCCI cycle (4 HCCI, the steady NVO table and the steady HCCI table called) was the start of the steady-state HCCI operation as all the changes in operation parameters, in terms of VVT phase, throttle opening, spark timing and fuel injection amount and timing have finished, and normal HCCI combustion was observed both in the simulation and experiment.

sec.p: In addition, the MFB curves of the experiment and the simulation were plotted, as shown in Figure 31. These curves clearly present the combustion characteristics during the SI to HCCI transition, such as start of combustion and combustion phase and duration. Figure 31 also demonstrates that by adopting six different tables, the model is capable of capturing the change in combustion characteristics during the transition process.

caption.p: MFB of Cylinder 4 during SI to HCCI mode transition.

sec.title: Cylinder-to-cylinder variations
sec.p: In the four-cylinder hybrid SI/HCCI research engine, the SI to HCCI switch order was set to 3–4–2–1 arbitrarily, according to the engine firing order. This order was also used in the model. All the cylinders experienced different conditions during the transition process due to the changes in VVT timing and throttle opening. The cylinder-to-cylinder variations will be discussed in this subsection. Figures 32 to 34 show the combustion pressure profiles for Cylinders 1–3. Relative AFRs and RGFs are compared in Figure 35 for all of the four cylinders, and Figure 36 shows the NOx emissions. The NIMEP of each cylinder is compared in Table 5.

caption.p: Pressure profiles during main combustion of Cylinder 1 in SI to HCCI mode transition.
Pressure profiles during main combustion of Cylinder 2 in SI to HCCI mode transition.
Pressure profiles during main combustion of Cylinder 3 in SI to HCCI mode transition.
Relative AFRs and RGFs of the four cylinders during SI to HCCI mode transition.
NOx emissions of the four cylinders during SI to HCCI mode transition.
NIMEP (bar) during SI to HCCI mode transition of validation run.

sec.p: In the last SI cycle (−1 SI), the RGFs of all four cylinders slightly dropped in the order 3–4–2–1 as the MAP was being increased. The relative AFRs of all cylinders except Cylinder 1, which was slightly lean due to a higher MAP, were decreased due to extra fuel injected. (The extra fuel in this cycle was necessary to avoid misfire in Cylinder 1. Otherwise, the mixture in Cylinder 1 would be too lean to be ignited, due to the increased MAP. This also suggests that individual fuel injection control for each cylinder is needed. As a result, NOx emissions were reduced in Cylinders 2, 3 and 4, but increased in Cylinder 1.

In the first HCCI cycle (1 HCCI), the largest difference in relative AFR and RGF for each cylinder was observed. This is mainly due to opening the throttle, causing the MAP to increase. The advance of EVC also played an important role as it resulted in trapping more residual gas from the previous cycle. Cylinders 3 and 4 experienced a SI/HCCI hybrid combustion because of a high RGF and so a relatively richer mixture. This resulted in a high peak temperature, causing increased NOx emissions. Cylinders 1 and 2 underwent a more HCCI-like combustion, which resulted in a reduction of NOx emissions.

In the second HCCI cycle (2 HCCI), the relative AFRs of all four cylinders were higher than the steady-state HCCI operations. This is because the MAP was at ambient level, but the trapped residual gas was lower than in steady-state HCCI operation due to the delay in VVT phasing. The cylinders that switched earlier had lower RGFs because of later EVC timings, and this caused the relative AFRs of all the cylinders to decline in the order 3–4–2–1. NOx emissions of all four cylinders were reduced in this cycle due to the low peak temperatures.

In the third HCCI cycle (3 HCCI), the relative AFRs and RGFs of all four cylinders moved to similar values, which were close to the steady-state conditions. The pressure profiles of all four cylinders were also close to steady-state HCCI operations. In the fourth HCCI cycle (4 HCCI), steady-state HCCI operation started.

It is worth pointing out that the odd pressure profiles of the first and second HCCI cycles in Figures 32 to 34 are because the pre-evaluated points in the transition HCCI table were a bit too far apart. Due to the transition HCCI table having five input parameters, it was necessary to have a larger distance between points, to reduce the number of evaluations required to generate the table.

The NIMEPs of each cylinder for transient cycles were compared in Table 5. Most of the errors were less than 20%, although several exceptions existed. Overall, the modelled results show a good agreement with the experimental data for an SI to HCCI transition simulation, and this provided a useful insight into this complicated process.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A hybrid SI/HCCI engine model has been presented. The model shows good agreement with experimental data, in terms of cylinder pressure, combustion phase, AFR, RGF and NOx emissions, both in HCCI and SI combustion modes and during a SI to HCCI combustion mode transition. In HCCI operation, the engine model also captured the cycle-to-cycle variations and the trends in the combustion phase and NOx emissions at different fuel split factors and pilot fuel injection timings.

The model provided an insight into the cyclic AFR and RGF fluctuations during the transition. These results suggested that the relatively slow change in the intake MAP and actuation time of the VVT are the main causes of undesired AFR and RGF fluctuations, and hence the NIMEP fluctuation. Large cylinder-to-cylinder AFR and RGF variations were also found during the transitions. Therefore, besides throttle opening control and VVT phasing, cyclic and individual cylinder fuel injection control is necessary to achieve a smooth transition.

Compared with other detailed chemistry engine models, this model is extremely fast, with a computational time of the order of seconds per engine cycle, such that parametric studies and model-based optimisation can be conducted in the order of hours. In addition, it has a potential to be used in hardware-in-loop applications. Compared with control-oriented engine models, the main strength of this approach is the capability of NOx emission prediction, and possibly more accurate CO and uHC emission predictions if a wall impingement sub-model is integrated in the original SRM model. The relatively higher accuracy of this model, in terms of cylinder pressure, AFR and RGF, is also an advantage.
